Joint Power Control and Data Size Selection for Over-the-Air Computation Aided Federated Learning

Xuming An, Rongfei Fan, Shiyuan Zuo, Han Hu, Hai Jiang, and Ning Zhang X. An, S. Zuo, and H. Hu are with the School of Information and Electronics, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, P. R. China. ({3120195381,3120210836,hhu}@bit.edu.cn). R. Fan is with the School of Cyberspace Science and Technology, Beijing 100081, P. R. China. (fanrongfei@bit.edu.cn).H. Jiang is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Alberta, Edmonton, AB T6G 1H9, Canada (hai1@ualberta.ca).N. Zhang is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Windsor, Windsor, ON, N9B 3P4, Canada (ning.zhang@uwindsor.ca).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as an appealing machine learning approach to deal with massive raw data generated at multiple mobile devices, which needs to aggregate the training model parameter of every mobile device at one base station (BS) iteratively. For parameter aggregating in FL, over-the-air computation is a spectrum-efficient solution, which allows all mobile devices to transmit their parameter-mapped signals concurrently to a BS. Due to heterogeneous channel fading and noise, there exists difference between the BS’s received signal and its desired signal, measured as the mean-squared error (MSE). To minimize the MSE, we propose to jointly optimize the signal amplification factors at the BS and the mobile devices as well as the data size (the number of data samples involved in local training) at every mobile device. The formulated problem is challenging to solve due to its non-convexity. To find the optimal solution, with some simplification on cost function and variable replacement, which still preserves equivalence, we transform the changed problem to be a bi-level problem equivalently. For the lower-level problem, optimal solution is found by enumerating every candidate solution from the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) condition. For the upper-level problem, the optimal solution is found by exploring its piecewise convexity. Numerical results show that our proposed method can greatly reduce the MSE and can help to improve the training performance of FL compared with benchmark methods.

Index Terms:
Over-the-air computation, federated learning, power control, data size selection.

I Introduction

In recent years, mobile devices, including smartphones and sensors, have experienced an exponential growth[1, 2]. A massive amount of data are generated from these mobile devices and promote various kinds of machine learning based applications, such as disaster warning based on digital twin, health monitoring via wearable devices, user habit learning through activities of smartphone holders, etc. [3]. Traditionally, machine learning approaches train a group of labeled data in a centralized way [4]. So mobile devices need to upload their local raw data to a central server, which may consume a large amount of wireless communication resources and cause privacy issues.

To tackle the above issues, a new distributed model training architecture is proposed, called Federated Learning (FL) [5, 6, 7, 8]. In an FL system, multiple mobile devices can collaboratively learn a common model under the coordination of a base station (BS) by iteratively exchanging model parameters between the BS and the mobile devices [9]. In each iteration, the model parameters are updated separately by every mobile device, based on the common model parameter broadcasted by the BS in last iteration and the dataset at local. Then every mobile device uploads the information of its updated model parameters to the BS, who afterwards fuses the received information and broadcasts the aggregated model parameter to every mobile device. In this process, the private raw data of each mobile device is not shared with the BS, and thus, the privacy is protected at some extent. When the BS performs data fusion, it takes a weighted sum of the information received from the mobile devices. The weight associated with a mobile device depends on its data size involved in its local training.

In FL, iterations of data exchange involve frequent multiple-access communications between mobile devices and the BS, which is spectrum- and/or energy-consuming, especially when there are a lot of mobile devices or the spectrum resources are limited. To overcome this problem, over-the-air computation can be adopted, which is able to directly calculate the summation of uploaded data that are transmitted simultaneously from multiple mobile devices to the BS [10, 11], thanks to the signal supposition property of the multiple-access channel. Over-the-air computation can achieve efficient data fusion, since uploading from multiple mobile devices happens simultaneously, and has shown great potential for not only FL but also wireless sensor network [12].

With general over-the-air computation (which may or may not work with FL), since the mobile devices’ transmitted signals experience heterogenous channel fading, the superposed signal cannot be exactly identical to the desired one. Hence mean-squared error (MSE) of the aggregated signal at the BS is usually taken as the performance metric. For an over-the-air computation system supporting FL, the MSE is also proved to be highly related to the training loss[13, 14, 15], which has also been disclosed in Section VI. To combat the heterogeneous channel fading and reduce the MSE, each mobile device amplifies its signal to be transmitted, and the BS also amplifies its received signal. The amplification factor at every mobile device and the BS are usually optimized jointly to minimize the MSE [12, 16]. It is always desired that the MSE should be reduced as much as possible.

When FL is conducted by over-the-air computation, recalling that the weight associated with a mobile device depends on its data size involved in its local training, it can be seen that the MSE is a function of these mobile devices’ data size. On the other hand, due to the existence of overfitting, it may not be necessary to use up all the available data samples for a general machine learning task [17]. FL is not an exception either [18]. Besides, using less data samples for local training can also help to save computation burden for every mobile device. Some literature on FL have already followed this idea [19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24]. Hence we can adjust the data size of each mobile device for local training.

Based on the above discussion, we can expect that the MSE can be further reduced by adjusting the data size of every mobile device in a proper way. Motivated by this, in this paper, we investigate an FL system supported by the over-the-air computation technique, and we jointly optimize each mobile device’s amplification factor and data size and the BS’s amplification factor, so as to minimize the MSE.

I-A Main Contributions

The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    A new perspective to reduce MSE: For an FL system supported by over-the-air computation, in addition to adjusting the amplification factors at the mobile devices and the BS, we propose to also adjust the data size of every mobile device in the local training stage, so as to further reduce the MSE. An optimization problem is formulated.

  • •

    Problem transformation: In the formulated problem, the cost function is with the amplification factors of the BS and mobile devices, denoted as a𝑎a and bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} for k𝑘kth mobile device, and the data size of the mobile devices, denoted as Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} for k𝑘kth mobile device, coupled. The cost function also involves the indicator function of Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k}. Either the coupling among a𝑎a, {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\}, and {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\} or the existence of indicator function with {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\} makes the cost function non-convex with the data size {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\}. To solve this challenge, we remove the indicator function from the cost function with proved equivalence and transform variable Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} to another variable βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}. With these operations, the cost function of the transformed problem is a convex function of {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\}, which paves the way for the optimal solving of an equivalently transformed problem in the sequel.

  • •

    Two-level structure to solve the transformed problem. The transformed problem is still not jointly convex with a𝑎a, {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\}, and {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\} because of the coupling among them. We propose to decouple them and decompose the problem into two levels. In the lower-level problem, the BS’s amplification factor a𝑎a is given, and we optimize the mobile devices’ amplification factors {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} and variables {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\}. In the upper-level problem, the BS’s amplification factor a𝑎a is optimized. Through this operation, the transformed problem is equivalent with the upper-level problem.

  • •

    Deriving closed-form solution for the lower-level problem: In the lower-level problem, the cost function is jointly convex with respect to the mobile devices’ amplification factors {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} and variables {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\}. To find the optimal solution of the lower-level problem, we investigates the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) condition of the lower-level problem and derive closed-form solution through exhaustively exploring the candidate solutions.

  • •

    Solving the upper-level problem with unclear convexity: For the upper-level problem, the convexity is unclear and hard to explore. To overcome this challenge, we discover the implicit convexity of the cost function over multiple intervals via the derived closed-form solution for the lower-level problem and show how to characterize these intervals. Accordingly, we use convex optimization techniques to find the optimal solution (i.e., the minimal MSE) in each interval, and the optimal solution of the upper-level problem can be found by comparing the minimal MSE values in all the intervals.

I-B Related Work

In general FL research (which does not adopt over-the-air computation), two major topics are on the analysis of convergence to optimal/stationary solution and the minimization of time delay to convergence. On convergence analysis, with some assumptions on the convexity and smoothness of the loss function for training, the gap to the global optimal loss function is analyzed versus the number of iterations, which is expected to converge to zero with a high convergence rate, under various configuration of step size and searching gradient [25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 19, 20, 21, 31, 32]. Specially, [19, 20, 21] assume the data size of each mobile device for local computing is adjustable. On time delay minimization, [31] proposes a hierarchical FL framework where there is one cloud server connecting multiple BS’s. The association between BS and mobile devices, together with mobile devices’ CPU frequency and allocated bandwidth for data uploading, are jointly optimized. [32] optimizes mobile devices’ CPU frequency, downloading and uploading date rate, and transmit power for a cell-free massive MIMO network.

For over-the-air computation research, MSE is an important metric and heterogeneous channel fading between mobile devices and the BS is the major cause to increase the MSE. To overcome the heterogenous channel fading, [12] and [16] are two pioneering works, in which the amplification factors at mobile devices and the BS are jointly optimized to minimize the MSE. In [33], the authors adopt multiple antennas to combat the channel fading between the mobile devices and the BS, and digital beamforming at every mobile device, together with the hybrid beamforming at the BS, are performed jointly to reduce the MSE.

Recently there have been some research efforts on FL systems supported by over-the-air computation technique. In [2], a multiple-band system with every band supporting the over-the-air computation is investigated. Time delay for one round of data aggregation under this setup is analyzed and is shown to outperform the system using the traditional digital orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) technique. In [34], convergence analysis is performed when there is no power control. This work shows that the FL with an over-the-air computation technique can achieve the optimal solution, when the number of enrolling mobile devices is infinite. The work in [13] performs a convergence analysis when there is power control at every mobile device. It is shown that FL with over-the-air computation technique can converge to the optimal solution, when the number of enrolling mobile devices is finite, and the converging speed is highly related to the MSE. In [35], private learning rate of every mobile device is set to combat the distortion caused by heterogeneous channel fading between every mobile device and the BS. To minimize the MSE, every mobile device’s learning rate is optimized dynamically over aggregation round in multiple-input-single-output (MISO) and multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) scenarios. In [36], with an energy consumption budget imposed on every mobile device, dynamic scheduling (which determines the group of nodes that can access the radio channel) in each round of aggregation is investigated to minimize the loss function. In [37, 15], a system aided by reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) is considered. The selection of the mobile devices, beamforming at the BS, and the phase shift of RIS’s every element in each round of iteration are optimized jointly to promote convergence by reducing the optimality gap [37] or by minimizing the MSE [15].

In summary, MSE is critical in FL systems supported by over-the-air computation technique, and in the literature, there have been research efforts on MSE reduction/minimization, by, for example, adjusting the amplification factors at the mobile devices and the BS. Different from the literature, especially [12] and [16], we propose a new dimension to minimize the MSE, i.e., in addition to adjusting the amplification factors, we propose to also adjust the data size of every mobile device in local training stage, so as to further reduce the MSE. Due to the inclusion of data size optimization, the formulated joint optimization problem is much harder to solve than problems with only amplification factor optimization. Accordingly, we develop a new method to solve our formulated joint optimization problem.

I-C Paper Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section II introduces the system model and problem formulation. Section III gives our structure to solve the problem. Sections IV and V demonstrate how the lower-level and upper-level optimization problems are solved, respectively. Section VII shows numerical results, followed by our conclusion in Section VIII.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

Consider a wireless network with one BS and K𝐾K wireless-linked mobile devices, which constitute the set 𝒦≜{1,2,…,K}≜𝒦12…𝐾\mathcal{K}\triangleq\{1,2,...,K\}. Each mobile device collects labelled data points independently and generates its own local data set. The data points collected by all the mobile devices are supposed to follow the same statistical heterogeneity [27]. For the k𝑘kth mobile device, we assume the associated data set is 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} with Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} elements. The l𝑙lth element, i.e., the l𝑙lth labelled data point, of set 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} can be written as {𝒙k,l,yk,l}subscript𝒙𝑘𝑙subscript𝑦𝑘𝑙\{\bm{x}_{k,l},{y}_{k,l}\} for l=1,2,…,Dk𝑙12…subscript𝐷𝑘l=1,2,...,{D}_{k}, where 𝒙k,l∈ℛNinsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑙superscriptℛsubscript𝑁in\bm{x}_{k,l}\in\mathcal{R}^{N_{\text{in}}} is the input vector and yk,l∈ℛsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑙ℛ{y}_{k,l}\in\mathcal{R} is the output scaler. To perform data analysis, with the collected data points from these K𝐾K mobile devices, the BS needs to train a parameter vector 𝒘∈ℛNin𝒘superscriptℛsubscript𝑁in\bm{w}\in\mathcal{R}^{N_{\text{in}}} (referred to as the training problem) to minimize 1∑k=1KDk​∑k=1K∑l=1Dkf​(𝒘,𝒙k,l,yk,l)1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑙1subscript𝐷𝑘𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑘𝑙subscript𝑦𝑘𝑙\frac{1}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{l=1}^{D_{k}}f\left(\bm{w},\bm{x}_{k,l},{y}_{k,l}\right), where f​(𝒘,𝒙k,l,yk,l)𝑓𝒘subscript𝒙𝑘𝑙subscript𝑦𝑘𝑙f\left(\bm{w},\bm{x}_{k,l},{y}_{k,l}\right) is the loss function to evaluate the error for approximating the output value yk,lsubscript𝑦𝑘𝑙{y}_{k,l} by the input vector 𝒙k,lsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑙\bm{x}_{k,l} under a selection of parameter 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}. FL is implemented in a distributed manner. It has a number of iterations. Each iteration has three rounds as follows.

  • •

    Round 1: With the most-updated parameter vector 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} broadcasted from the BS to every mobile device, every mobile device utilizes its local data set to generate a local gradient vector of the parameter vector;

  • •

    Round 2: Every mobile device uploads its local gradient vector of parameter vector 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} to the BS;

  • •

    Round 3: The BS aggregates the gradient vectors from every mobile device to generate a new parameter vector 𝒘𝒘\bm{w}.

The above procedure is repeated until the parameter vector converges or there are a sufficient number of iterations.

Take the t𝑡tth iteration as an example. In Round 1, to save computation burden and reduce the MSE for gradient vector aggregation (to be explained in the sequel), not all the local data points are utilized for local updating.

Suppose a number of Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} data points are selected from the k𝑘kth mobile device’s local dataset for local updating, which is also called as data size of k𝑘kth mobile device. Then there is Sk≤Dk,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦S_{k}\leq D_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Further, to promise the performance of FL, the total number of data points involved in training should be no less than a threshold STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} (ST≤∑k=1KDksubscript𝑆𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘S_{T}\leq\sum_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}), i.e., ∑k=1KSk≥ST.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘subscript𝑆𝑇\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}\geq S_{T}.

In Round 2, the technique of over-the-air computation is adopted, which is efficient when the receiver wants to collect the weighted sum of multiple transmitters. Then there is an upper bound of bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}, which is denoted as bkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}^{\max} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. On the other hand, there is no limitation on a𝑎a at the BS. The reason is as follows. After receiving the aggregated signal at the BS, the BS can first digitalize the received signal through quantization. Then the BS can amplify the digitalized signal at any ratio. For the defined MSE in (3), the ℐ​(Sk)ℐsubscript𝑆𝑘\mathcal{I}(S_{k}) would be zero if Sk=0subscript𝑆𝑘0S_{k}=0 and would be one otherwise. This is because when Sk=0subscript𝑆𝑘0S_{k}=0, the k𝑘kth mobile device actually does not take part in the gradient aggregation, and the associated MSE will not count the gradient aggregation distortion lead by k𝑘kth mobile device.

In Round 3 for the t𝑡tth iteration of FL procedure, the BS utilizes the recovered signal 𝒛^tsubscript^𝒛𝑡\hat{\bm{z}}_{t}, which represents an approximation of 𝒛tsubscript𝒛𝑡\bm{z}_{t}, to update the parameter vector 𝒘𝒘\bm{w} as follows

𝒘t+1=𝒘t−η​𝒛^tsubscript𝒘𝑡1subscript𝒘𝑡𝜂subscript^𝒛𝑡\bm{w}_{t+1}=\bm{w}_{t}-\eta\hat{\bm{z}}_{t} (4)

where η𝜂\eta is a pre-defined step-size.

In the procedure of FL with over-the-air computation, the MSE as expressed in (3), which represents the distortion between 𝒛^tsubscript^𝒛𝑡\hat{\bm{z}}_{t} and 𝒛tsubscript𝒛𝑡\bm{z}_{t}, has been proved to be highly related with the training loss[13, 14, 15], which has also been disclosed in Section VI. To suppress the training loss, as expected in every training task, the MSE should be kept as small as possible. Thus, in this paper, our target is to minimize the MSE, through optimizing the variables bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}, Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} and a𝑎a. Accordingly, the following optimization problem is formulated.

Problem 1

III Optimal Solution Structure

Looking into Problem 1’s objective function, it is the summation of the term a2​σ2superscript𝑎2superscript𝜎2a^{2}\sigma^{2} and (a​bk​hk−(Sk∑k=1KSk))2​ck​ℐ​(Sk>0)superscript𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘2subscript𝑐𝑘ℐsubscript𝑆𝑘0\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\left(\frac{S_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}}\right)\right)^{2}{c_{k}{\mathcal{I}\left(S_{k}>0\right)}} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, which are always no less than zero. Intuitively, the cost function will achieve its minimal value a2​σ2superscript𝑎2superscript𝜎2a^{2}\sigma^{2} if {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} and {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\} are properly selected to make the term (a​bk​hk−(Sk∑k=1KSk))2​ck​ℐ​(Sk>0)superscript𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘2subscript𝑐𝑘ℐsubscript𝑆𝑘0\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\left(\frac{S_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}}\right)\right)^{2}{c_{k}{\mathcal{I}\left(S_{k}>0\right)}} to be zero for every k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, especially considering that bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} can be set separately to make a​bk​hk𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘ab_{k}h_{k} offset Sk∑k=1KSksubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘\frac{S_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}} and Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} can be set as 0 even this offset cannot be achieved for k𝑘k. However, due to the existence of upper bound of bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} defined in (5a), we cannot promise to make the above offset happen for every k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. Moreover, we cannot always require Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} to be zero for every k𝑘k such that the above offset does not succeed, because of the constraint (5c) imposed on {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\}. In one word, Problem 1’s objective function cannot achieve its lower bound a2​σ2superscript𝑎2superscript𝜎2a^{2}\sigma^{2} easily.

What is even worse, in the cost function of Problem 1, it can be also observed that: 1) there exists indicator function ℐ​(Sk>0)ℐsubscript𝑆𝑘0\mathcal{I}(S_{k}>0) for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, 2) the set of {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\} are coupled each other in the term Sk∑k=1KSksubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘\frac{S_{k}}{\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, 3) a𝑎a and bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} are entangled for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. For the above three listed observations, any one of them can lead to the non-convexity of Problem 1, which brings challenge into problem solving. In this sequel, we will show how to find the optimal solution of Problem 1 through simplification, transformation, decomposition, and subsequent analysis on the decomposed problems.

Problem 1 is equivalent with Problem 2, which is given as

III-C Decomposition

The cost function of Problem 3 is a convex function of {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\} and {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\}. However, it is not a joint convex function of a𝑎a, {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} and {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\}. Thus, Problem 3 is still non-convex. In the following, we will decompose Problem 3 into two levels. In the lower level, with the variable a𝑎a given, all other variables are optimized, in which case the cost function E​(a)𝐸𝑎E(a) is achieved. In the upper level, the variable a𝑎a is optimized to find the minimal E​(a)𝐸𝑎E(a). Specifically, the lower-level optimization problem is given as

Problem 4
E​(a)≜min{bk},{βk}≜𝐸𝑎subscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘\displaystyle E(a)\triangleq\mathop{\min}\limits_{\{b_{k}\},\{\beta_{k}\}} ∑k=1K(a​bk​hk−βk)2​ck+a2​σ2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘2subscript𝑐𝑘superscript𝑎2superscript𝜎2\displaystyle\quad\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2}{c_{k}}+a^{2}\sigma^{2}
s.t. 0≤bk≤bkmax,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence0subscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\quad 0{\leq}b_{k}\leq b_{k}^{\max},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (15a)
0≤βk≤βkmax,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence0subscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\quad 0{\leq}\beta_{k}\leq\beta_{k}^{\max},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (15b)
∑k=1Kβk=1.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘1\displaystyle\quad\sum_{k=1}^{K}\beta_{k}=1. (15c)

The upper-level optimization problem is given as

Problem 5
minasubscript𝑎\displaystyle\mathop{\min}\limits_{a} E​(a)𝐸𝑎\displaystyle\quad E(a)
s.t. a>0.𝑎0\displaystyle\quad a>0. (16a)

It can be checked Problem 5 is equivalent to Problem 3.

As a summary, Problem 1 is equivalent with Problem 2 according to Lemma 1, and Problem 2 is equivalent with Problem3 by Lemma 2. Also with the equivalence between Problem 3 and Problem 5 as just disclosed, we can claim the equivalence between Problem 1 and Problem 5. It should be also noticed that the role of Problem 4 is to return the value of Problem 5’s cost function for an input of a𝑎a.

IV Optimal Solution for the Lower-Level Problem (Problem 4)

For the lower-level optimization problem, i.e., Problem 4, its cost function is a joint convex function of {bk}subscript𝑏𝑘\{b_{k}\} and {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\}, and its feasible solution is also convex. Hence Problem 4 is a convex optimization problem. In addition, it also satisfies Slater’s condition. In this case, Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) condition can serve as a necessary and sufficient condition of the optimal solution of Problem 4 [38]. Specifically, the KKT condition can be given as follows

−2​(a​bk​hk−βk)​ck+λ−zk+yk=0,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence2𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘𝜆subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle-2(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}){c_{k}}+\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}=0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17a)
2​(a​bk​hk−βk)​ck​a​hk+μk−γk=0,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence2𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝑐𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘subscript𝛾𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle 2(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}){c_{k}}ah_{k}+\mu_{k}-\gamma_{k}=0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17b)
0≤βk≤βkmax,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence0subscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle 0\leq\beta_{k}\leq\beta_{k}^{\max},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17c)
0≤bk≤bkmax,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence0subscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle 0\leq b_{k}\leq b_{k}^{\max},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17d)
∑k=1Kβk=1,superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘1\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{K}\beta_{k}=1, (17e)
zk​βk=0,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle z_{k}\beta_{k}=0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17f)
yk​(βk−βkmax)=0,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle y_{k}(\beta_{k}-\beta_{k}^{\max})=0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (17g)

zk≥0;yk≥0;γk≥0;μk≥0,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝑧𝑘0formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑘0formulae-sequencesubscript𝛾𝑘0formulae-sequencesubscript𝜇𝑘0for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle z_{k}\geq 0;y_{k}\geq 0;\gamma_{k}\geq 0;\mu_{k}\geq 0,\forall k\in\mathcal{K} (17j)

where zksubscript𝑧𝑘z_{k}, yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k}, γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k}, and μksubscript𝜇𝑘\mu_{k} are non-negative Lagrange multipliers associated with the constraints βk≥0subscript𝛽𝑘0\beta_{k}\geq 0, βk≤βmaxsubscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝛽\beta_{k}\leq\beta_{\max}, bk≥0subscript𝑏𝑘0b_{k}\geq 0, and bk≤bkmaxsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}\leq b_{k}^{\max}, respectively, and λ𝜆\lambda is the Lagrange multiplier associated with the constraint in (17e).

IV-A Characterizing Candidate Optimal Solutions

We will first find optimal solutions of Problem 4. To achieve this, special properties of an optimal solution of Problem 4 will be analyzed based on listed KKT condition in (17). From (17a) in the KKT condition, we have

(λ−zk+yk)=2​ck​(a​hk​bk−βk),∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequence𝜆subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘2subscript𝑐𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\left(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)=2{c_{k}}\left(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (18)

Substituting the expression of 2​(a​hk​bk−βk)2𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘2\left(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k}\right) in (18) into (17b), we have

(λ−zk+yk)×(a​hk)=(γk−μk),∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequence𝜆subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\left(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)\times(ah_{k})=\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (19)

Next, we investigate two cases: 1) λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0; 2) λ≠0𝜆0\lambda\neq 0.

IV-A1 Case with λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0

When λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, equation (19) becomes

(−zk+yk)×(a​hk)=(γk−μk),∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\left(-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)\times(ah_{k})=\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (20)

which implies that the term (−zk+yk)subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘\left(-z_{k}+y_{k}\right) and the term (γk−μk)subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right) should be both positive or both negative. In addition, from (17f) and (17g), it can be seen that at least one of zksubscript𝑧𝑘z_{k} and yksubscript𝑦𝑘y_{k} (which are nonnegative) should be zero. Similarly, from (17h) and (17i), at least one of γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} and μksubscript𝜇𝑘\mu_{k} (which are nonnegative) should be zero. We have three possible scenarios as follows.

    Scenario I: (γk−μk)>0subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘0\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)>0. Then from (17h), we have bk=0subscript𝑏𝑘0b_{k}=0. On the other hand, (γk−μk)>0subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘0\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)>0 also implies that (−zk+yk)>0subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0\left(-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)>0 according to (20), which further implies that yk>0subscript𝑦𝑘0y_{k}>0 and zk=0subscript𝑧𝑘0z_{k}=0. In this case, there is βk=βkmaxsubscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max} according to (17g). So in this scenario, there is bk=0subscript𝑏𝑘0b_{k}=0 and βk=βkmaxsubscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max}. However, the MSE in this scenario can be further reduced by setting bk=min⁡(bkmax,βkmaxa​hk)>0subscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘0b_{k}=\min\left(b_{k}^{\max},\frac{\beta_{k}^{\max}}{ah_{k}}\right)>0 with βk=βkmaxsubscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max}. Therefore, the optimal solution does not happen in this scenario and we discard it.

    Scenario II: (γk−μk)<0subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘0\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)<0. Similar to the discussion in Scenario I, we have γk=0subscript𝛾𝑘0\gamma_{k}=0, μk>0subscript𝜇𝑘0\mu_{k}>0, yk=0subscript𝑦𝑘0y_{k}=0, and zk>0subscript𝑧𝑘0z_{k}>0. Correspondingly, there is bk=bkmaxsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}=b_{k}^{\max} according to (17i) and βk=0subscript𝛽𝑘0\beta_{k}=0 according to (17f). However, the MSE in this case can be further reduced by setting bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} as 0 rather than bkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}^{\max} when βk=0subscript𝛽𝑘0\beta_{k}=0. Hence this scenario is also discarded.

  • •

    Scenario III: (γk−μk)=0subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘0\left(\gamma_{k}-\mu_{k}\right)=0. Since at least one of γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} and μksubscript𝜇𝑘\mu_{k} (which are nonnegative) should be zero, we have γk=μk=0subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘0\gamma_{k}=\mu_{k}=0. Similar to the discussion in Scenario I and II, we also have zk=yk=0subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0z_{k}=y_{k}=0. From (18), we have

    βk=a​hk​bk,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝛽𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\beta_{k}=ah_{k}b_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (21)

    referred to as Candidate Solution I for Problem 4. It can be seen that when βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} and bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} satisfies (21), the KKT condition is satisfied, and the cost function of Problem 4 achieves its minimal value a2​σ2superscript𝑎2superscript𝜎2a^{2}\sigma^{2}.

IV-A2 Case with λ≠0𝜆0\lambda\neq 0

We investigate three scenarios: (λ−zk+yk)=0𝜆subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})=0, (λ−zk+yk)>0𝜆subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})>0, and (λ−zk+yk)<0𝜆subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k})<0.

    • –

      If zk>0subscript𝑧𝑘0z_{k}>0, we have βk=0subscript𝛽𝑘0\beta_{k}=0 according to (17f), which further implies bk=0subscript𝑏𝑘0b_{k}=0 for minimizing the term (a​bk​hk−βk)2​cksuperscript𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘2subscript𝑐𝑘(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k})^{2}c_{k} in the expression of MSE.     Candidate Solution II: λ<0𝜆0\lambda<0, γk=μk=zk=0subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘subscript𝑧𝑘0\gamma_{k}=\mu_{k}=z_{k}=0, yk>0subscript𝑦𝑘0y_{k}>0, and (λ−zk+yk)=0𝜆subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0\left(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)=0. βk=βkmaxsubscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max} and bk=βkmaxa​hksubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘b_{k}=\frac{\beta_{k}^{\max}}{ah_{k}}.     Candidate Solution V: λ<0𝜆0\lambda<0, γk=zk=yk=0subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0\gamma_{k}=z_{k}=y_{k}=0, μk>0subscript𝜇𝑘0\mu_{k}>0, and (λ−zk+yk)<0𝜆subscript𝑧𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘0\left(\lambda-z_{k}+y_{k}\right)<0. bk=bkmaxsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}=b_{k}^{\max} and βk∈(a​hk​bkmax,βkmax]subscript𝛽𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}\in\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max},\beta_{k}^{\max}\right]. It can be seen that, if λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0, then all mobile devices take Candidate Solution I, in which we still need to determine the exact values of bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} and βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} for the k𝑘kth mobile device. If λ<0𝜆0\lambda<0, then the k𝑘kth mobile device takes Candidate Solution II if a​hk​bkmax≥βkmax𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}\geq\beta_{k}^{\max}, and takes Candidate Solution IV or V if a​hk​bkmax<βkmax𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}<\beta_{k}^{\max}. If λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0, only Candidate Solution III is active and all the other candidate solutions (including Candidate Solutions I, II, IV, and V) are precluded because the associated λ𝜆\lambda values of these candidate solutions are either zero or positive. On other hand, Candidate Solution III cannot work for every k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} since ∑k=1Kβksuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝛽𝑘\sum_{k=1}^{K}\beta_{k} should be 1 for Problem 4 while βk=0subscript𝛽𝑘0\beta_{k}=0 in Candidate Solution III. So we can omit Candidate Solution III.

For the other four candidate solutions with λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0 or λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0, i.e., Candidate Solutions I, II, IV, and V, since we only need one optimal solution of Problem 4, we will first try λ<0𝜆0\lambda<0. If each mobile device’s associated solution (i.e., Candidate Solution II, IV, or V) is feasible, then the mobile devices’ solutions form optimal solution of Problem 4; otherwise, we try λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0 with Candidate Solution I.

IV-B Finding An Optimal Solution of Problem 4

We partition set 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} into two disjoint subsets, 𝒦1subscript𝒦1\mathcal{K}_{1} and 𝒦2subscript𝒦2\mathcal{K}_{2} such that 𝒦=𝒦1∪𝒦2𝒦subscript𝒦1subscript𝒦2\mathcal{K}=\mathcal{K}_{1}\cup\mathcal{K}_{2}, 𝒦1={k|a​hk​bkmax≥βkmax,k∈𝒦}subscript𝒦1conditional-set𝑘formulae-sequence𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘𝑘𝒦\mathcal{K}_{1}=\{k|ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}\geq\beta_{k}^{\max},k\in\mathcal{K}\}, and 𝒦2={k|a​hk​bkmax<βkmax,k∈𝒦}subscript𝒦2conditional-set𝑘formulae-sequence𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘𝑘𝒦\mathcal{K}_{2}=\{k|ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}<\beta_{k}^{\max},k\in\mathcal{K}\}. Consider λ<0𝜆0\lambda<0. As aforementioned, for k∈𝒦1𝑘subscript𝒦1k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}, the k𝑘kth mobile device’s solution is βk=βkmaxsubscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max} and bk=βkmaxa​hksubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘b_{k}=\frac{\beta_{k}^{\max}}{ah_{k}} (Candidate Solution II); for k∈𝒦2𝑘subscript𝒦2k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}, the k𝑘kth mobile device’s solution is bk=bkmaxsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}=b_{k}^{\max}, βk=βkmaxsubscript𝛽𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}=\beta_{k}^{\max} (Candidate Solution IV) or βk∈(a​hk​bkmax,βkmax]subscript𝛽𝑘𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}\in\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max},\beta_{k}^{\max}\right] (Candidate Solution V). We need to verify whether or not a λ𝜆\lambda exists to make all these happen.

From (18) and the facts that bk=bkmaxsubscript𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}=b_{k}^{\max} and zk=0subscript𝑧𝑘0z_{k}=0 for k∈𝒦2𝑘subscript𝒦2k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}, βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} can be written as a function with λ𝜆\lambda, which is given as

βk​(λ)=(a​hk​bkmax−λ2​ck−yk2​ck),∀k∈𝒦2.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛽𝑘𝜆𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝜆2subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘2subscript𝑐𝑘for-all𝑘subscript𝒦2\beta_{k}(\lambda)=\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}-\frac{\lambda}{2{c_{k}}}-\frac{y_{k}}{2{c_{k}}}\right),\forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}. (22)

The procedure to work out the optimal bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} and βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} of Problem 4 for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} can be given as follows. Recalling the expression of athsubscript𝑎tha_{\text{th}} in (27), it can be checked that

∑k∈𝒦βk=∑k∈𝒦1βkmax+∑k∈𝒦2ath​hk​bkmax=∑k∈𝒦1βkmax+(1−∑k∈𝒦1βkmax)=1.subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝛽𝑘absentsubscript𝑘subscript𝒦1superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘subscript𝑘subscript𝒦2subscript𝑎thsubscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘missing-subexpressionabsentsubscript𝑘subscript𝒦1superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘1subscript𝑘subscript𝒦1superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘missing-subexpressionabsent1\begin{array}[]{ll}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\beta_{k}&=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}}\beta_{k}^{\max}+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}}a_{\text{th}}h_{k}b_{k}^{\max}\\ &=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}}\beta_{k}^{\max}+\left(1-\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}}\beta_{k}^{\max}\right)\\ &=1.\end{array} (28)

With the above optimal solution of bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} and βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} when a≥ath𝑎subscript𝑎tha\geq a_{\text{th}} , the cost function of Problem 4 achieves its optimal value a2​σ2superscript𝑎2superscript𝜎2a^{2}\sigma^{2}.

Overall, the method for finding an optimal solution of Problem 4 is given in Algorithm 1.

For computation complexity of Algorithm 1, the worst case happens when ∑k∈𝒦1βkmax≤1subscript𝑘subscript𝒦1superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘1\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}}\beta_{k}^{\max}\leq 1 and a<ath𝑎subscript𝑎tha<a_{\text{th}}. The computation burden comes from the bisection search of λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} and the calculation of βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} and bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, whose complexity can be written as O​(log⁡(λminδB)​K)𝑂subscript𝜆subscript𝛿𝐵𝐾O\left(\log\left(\frac{\lambda_{\min}}{\delta_{B}}\right)K\right), where δBsubscript𝛿𝐵\delta_{B} is the tolerance for bisection search.

V Optimal Solution for Upper-Level Problem (Problem 5)

In this section, the optimal a𝑎a of Problem 5, which is also optimal for Problem 2, is to be found. However, the convexity of E​(a)𝐸𝑎E(a), which is the cost function of Problem 5, is unclear and hard to explore. This challenge will be overcome by our proposed solution given in the following.

As the value of a𝑎a grows, it can be checked that the set 𝒦1subscript𝒦1\mathcal{K}_{1} enlarges and the set 𝒦2subscript𝒦2\mathcal{K}_{2} shrinks. Hence both set 𝒦1subscript𝒦1\mathcal{K}_{1} and set 𝒦2subscript𝒦2\mathcal{K}_{2} are functions of a𝑎a, which are denoted as 𝒦1​(a)subscript𝒦1𝑎\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and 𝒦2​(a)subscript𝒦2𝑎\mathcal{K}_{2}(a), respectively, in this section. Similarly the λ∗superscript𝜆\lambda^{*} solving the equation in (24) is also a function of a𝑎a, which is denoted as λ∗​(a)superscript𝜆𝑎\lambda^{*}(a) in this section.

As a𝑎a grows, the cardinality of 𝒦1​(a)subscript𝒦1𝑎\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) will enlarge from 0 to K𝐾K, while the cardinality of 𝒦2​(a)subscript𝒦2𝑎\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) will shrink from K𝐾K to 0 at the same time. Then there would be multiple intervals of a𝑎a. When a𝑎a varies within any interval, the cardinality of the set 𝒦1​(a)subscript𝒦1𝑎\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and 𝒦2​(a)subscript𝒦2𝑎\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) keep unchanged. When a𝑎a grows from one interval to the next interval, the cardinality of the set 𝒦1​(a)subscript𝒦1𝑎\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and 𝒦2​(a)subscript𝒦2𝑎\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) will change. To characterizing these intervals, the boundaries of every interval of a𝑎a need to be found.

Define sk≜βkmaxhk​bkmax≜subscript𝑠𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘s_{k}\triangleq\frac{\beta_{k}^{\max}}{h_{k}b_{k}^{\max}} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} and sort sksubscript𝑠𝑘s_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} in ascending order, such that s(1)≤s(2)≤s(3)​⋯≤s(K)subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2subscript𝑠3⋯subscript𝑠𝐾s_{(1)}\leq s_{(2)}\leq s_{(3)}\cdots\leq s_{(K)}, where s(k)∈{s1,s2,⋯,sK}subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2⋯subscript𝑠𝐾s_{(k)}\in\{s_{1},s_{2},\cdots,s_{K}\} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}.

    When a∈(0,s(1))𝑎0subscript𝑠1a\in(0,s_{(1)}), |𝒦1​(a)|=0subscript𝒦1𝑎0|\mathcal{K}_{1}(a)|=0 and |𝒦2​(a)|=Ksubscript𝒦2𝑎𝐾|\mathcal{K}_{2}(a)|=K.

    When a∈[s(k),s(k+1))𝑎subscript𝑠𝑘subscript𝑠𝑘1a\in[s_{(k)},s_{(k+1)}), |𝒦1​(a)|=ksubscript𝒦1𝑎𝑘|\mathcal{K}_{1}(a)|=k and |𝒦2​(a)|=(K−k)subscript𝒦2𝑎𝐾𝑘|\mathcal{K}_{2}(a)|=\left(K-k\right) for k∈𝒦∖{K}𝑘𝒦𝐾k\in\mathcal{K}\setminus\{K\}.

Remark 2

Based on Lemma 4, when a𝑎a is in a region in which 𝒦1​(a)subscript𝒦1𝑎\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and 𝒦2​(a)subscript𝒦2𝑎\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) do not change, the function (F​(a))2superscript𝐹𝑎2(F(a))^{2} is also a convex function with a𝑎a since it is a composition of a convex function F​(a)𝐹𝑎F(a) with a non-decreasing convex function z​(x)=x2​(when ​x≥0)𝑧𝑥superscript𝑥2when 𝑥0z(x)=x^{2}\left(\text{when~{}}x\geq 0\right), which is still convex according to [39].

According to Remark 2, the cost function of Problem 5, i.e., E​(a)𝐸𝑎E(a) in (29), becomes a convex function with a𝑎a, when the sets 𝒦1​(a)subscript𝒦1𝑎\mathcal{K}_{1}(a), 𝒦2I​(a)superscriptsubscript𝒦2I𝑎\mathcal{K}_{2}^{\text{I}}(a), and 𝒦2II​(a)superscriptsubscript𝒦2II𝑎\mathcal{K}_{2}^{\text{II}}(a) are unchanged. Then the optimal value of a𝑎a for a∈𝒜m𝑎subscript𝒜𝑚a\in\mathcal{A}_{m} (m=0,1,…,M𝑚01…𝑀m=0,1,...,M) can be found accordingly. Then the optimal value of a𝑎a for a∈(0,∞)𝑎0a\in(0,\infty) can be found by comparing the minimal cost function in intervals 𝒜0subscript𝒜0\mathcal{A}_{0}, 𝒜1subscript𝒜1\mathcal{A}_{1},… 𝒜M+1subscript𝒜𝑀1\mathcal{A}_{M+1}.

Complexity Analysis: To find the optimal value of a𝑎a, the major computation complexity is on the Golden search method for every sub-interval of ℬmsubscriptℬ𝑚\mathcal{B}_{m} (m=0,1,…,M𝑚01…𝑀m=0,1,...,M), with total worst-case complexity being O​(K2)𝑂superscript𝐾2O(K^{2}) for all sub-intervals of ℬ0,ℬ1,…,ℬMsubscriptℬ0subscriptℬ1…subscriptℬ𝑀\mathcal{B}_{0},\mathcal{B}_{1},...,\mathcal{B}_{M}.

VI Convergence and Optimality for Training

In terms of convergence and optimality, [15, 13, 14] have already investigated this topic for a general over-the-air computation aided FL system. According to their results, our proposed method can achieve convergence or even zero optimality gap, under some mild conditions. It is worth mentioning that the derived optimality gap is highly related to the MSE of aggregation, which also necessities MSE minimization as we do in this paper.

To be specific, for a non-convex loss function being L𝐿L-smooth (whose definition can be found in [15, 13, 14]), which is applicable for the training of a neural network, the associated results on convergence or optimality gap in [15, 13, 14] are given as follows:

  1. 1.

    [15] investigates an intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) enhanced over-the-air computation aided FL system, which also applies for our considered system since the IRS system can also realize any channel gain between mobile devices and the BS assumed in this paper. With a general setup of signal amplification factors at both mobile devices and the BS, the average norm of the cost function’s gradient over T𝑇T iterations is upper bounded as

    1T​∑t=0T−1𝔼​{∥∇f​(𝒘t)∥2}≤O​(1T2​∑t=0T−1𝔼​{∥εt∥2})+O​(1T​(f​(𝒘0)−f∗)),1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥∇𝑓subscript𝒘𝑡2𝑂1superscript𝑇2superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜀𝑡2𝑂1𝑇𝑓subscript𝒘0superscript𝑓\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\nabla f(\bm{w}_{t})\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\leq O\left({\frac{1}{T^{2}}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}}\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\varepsilon_{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\right)+O\left(\frac{1}{T}\left(f\left(\bm{w}_{0}\right)-f^{*}\right)\right), (32)

    where εtsubscript𝜀𝑡\varepsilon_{t} denotes the aggregation error, 𝔼​{∥εt∥2}𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜀𝑡2\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\varepsilon_{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\} is the MSE of aggregation at the t−limit-from𝑡t-th round of iteration, 𝒘0subscript𝒘0\bm{w}_{0} and 𝒘tsubscript𝒘𝑡\bm{w}_{t} represent the global parameter vector at the beginning of training and the t−limit-from𝑡t-th round of iteration respectively, f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} is the minimal achievable value of the loss function f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot). It can be observed that for a fixed T𝑇T, the averaged norm of loss function’s gradient is highly related to the MSE of aggregation in each step of iteration. Moreover, as T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty, the averaged norm of loss functions’s gradient trends to be zero. This verifies the convergence of our proposed method.

  2. 2.

    With τ𝜏\tau-Polyak-Łojasiewicz condition (whose definition can be found in [13, 14]), according to [13, 14], the optimality gap can be written as

    𝔼​{f​(𝒘T)}−f∗≤O​(1T​𝔼​{∥εt∥2})+O​(1T​(f​(𝒘0)−f∗))+1T​W,𝔼𝑓subscript𝒘𝑇superscript𝑓𝑂1𝑇𝔼superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜀𝑡2𝑂1𝑇𝑓subscript𝒘0superscript𝑓1𝑇𝑊\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\{f\left(\bm{w}_{T}\right)\}-f^{*}\leq O\left({\frac{1}{T}}\mathbb{E}\left\{\left\lVert\varepsilon_{t}\right\rVert^{2}\right\}\right)+O\left({\frac{1}{T}}\left(f\left(\bm{w}_{0}\right)-f^{*}\right)\right)+{\frac{1}{T}}W, (33)

    where W𝑊W is a constant item related to system parameters such as the L𝐿L, τ𝜏\tau, and the upper bound of local gradient’s variance. This result can verify not only the convergence but also the ability of achieving zero optimality gap for our proposed method.

VII Numerical Results

In this section, numerical results are presented to evaluate the performance of our proposed method. Default system settings are given as follows. There are K=20𝐾20K=20 mobile devices in the FL system [26]. The Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} for k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,...,K are randomly generated to be 3979, 3974, 3985, 3933, 4026, 3984, 3972, 3961, 3991, 3986, 4051, 3972, 3921, 3991, 3983, 3937, 3958, 4058, 4033, and 4051, respectively. cksubscript𝑐𝑘c_{k} is selected to be 1 for ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} is selected to be 400004000040000.

We compare the performance of our proposed method with the AirFedSGD method [40], the Transmission Power Control (referred to as the TPC method in the sequel) in [16], and the Computation Optimal Policy (referred to as the COP method in the sequel) in [12]. The AirFedSGD method is the traditional FedSGD method [5] adapted to the environment of over-the-air computation, which sets the signal amplification factor bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} to be inversely proportional to the channel gain for every mobile device k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. The amplification factor of the received signal at the BS a𝑎a is simply set as 1|𝒦|1𝒦\frac{1}{\left\lvert\mathcal{K}\right\rvert}. The TPC method follows the idea of AirFedSGD but considers the case that the channel condition may be poor. In this case, the associated signal amplification factor has to be very high by following AirFedSGD method but cannot be achieved due to the limit of mobile device’s transmit power. The TPC method regulates the signal amplification factor to be at its maximal transmit power level for this case. The amplification factor of the received signal at the BS a𝑎a is further optimized so as to minimize the aggregation MSE, which generates a closed-form solution. The COP method optimizes the signal amplification factor bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} and the amplification factor of the received signal at the BS a𝑎a jointly to minimize the aggregation MSE. For the above three methods, they all select Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} as Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}.

For ease of comparison with the AirFedSGD, the TPC, and the COP method, we also adopt their parameter setup [12, 16] of σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}, and bkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}^{\max} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} as follows: σ2=1superscript𝜎21\sigma^{2}=1; the channel coefficient hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} are i.i.d Rayleigh distributed random variables with mean being h¯=π/(4−π)¯ℎ𝜋4𝜋\bar{h}=\sqrt{{\pi}/{\left(4-\pi\right)}} (this implies a variance being 1); bkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}^{\max} is set as 1010\sqrt{10} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. The code to realize our numerical results is available at https://github.com/anxuming/FedAirComp.git.

VII-A MSE Improvement

Fig. 4, Fig. 4, Fig. 4, and Fig. 4 plot the MSE versus various system parameters for our proposed method, the AirFedSGD method, the TPC method, and the COP method. It can be seen that our proposed method can always achieve an MSE no larger than the one under the COP method. Moreover, the COP method also achieves a lower MSE than the ones under the AirFedSGD method and the TPC method. These results demonstrates the effectiveness of our proposed method. The reason behind can be explained as follows. Our proposed method minimizes the MSE through optimizing one more dimension of variable Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, while the COP method simply sets Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} as Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. Compared with the COP method, both the AirFedSGD method and the TPC method offer a sub optimal solution for minimizing the MSE also with Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} being set as Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. Hence they achieve higher MSE than the COP method. Since the AirFedSGD method and the TPC method are always inferior to the COP method, we will mainly analyze the performance of our proposed method and the COP method in the following.

Fig. 4 shows the MSE versus the minimal required data amount STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} for our proposed method, the AirFedSGD method, the TPC method, and the COP method. In the COP method, each mobile device utilizes all its data in its local training, and thus, its MSE does not change with STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T}. In our proposed method, the MSE increases as STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} grows. This is because the growing STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} means that the feasible region of Problem 2 shrinks, and thus, its cost function (i.e., the MSE) increases. When ST=∑k=1KDKsubscript𝑆𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝐾S_{T}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{D_{K}}, the MSE of our proposed method and the COP method are the same. This is because, to satisfy ST=∑k=1KDKsubscript𝑆𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝐾S_{T}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{D_{K}}, each mobile device in our proposed method has to use all its data in its local training.

Fig. 4 shows the MSE versus the number of mobile devices K𝐾K. When a number of K𝐾K mobile devices are investigated, we select the first K𝐾K mobile devices from the set of 20 mobile devices described at the beginning of this section. From Fig. 4, it can be seen that the MSE under the CoP method first goes down with K𝐾K and then increase after K=17𝐾17K=17. The reason is as follows. When the number of mobile devices increases, βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} of the k𝑘kth mobile device tends to decrease (recalling that the summation of βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k}’s is equal to one). Thus, the k𝑘kth mobile device can have a smaller term (a​hk​bk−βk)2superscript𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘2(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k})^{2} in the expression of MSE, leading to a decreasing trend of MSE. On the other hand, the increase of the number of mobile devices means that there are more terms (a​hk​bk−βk)2superscript𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑏𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘2(ah_{k}b_{k}-\beta_{k})^{2} in the expression of MSE, leading to an increasing trend of MSE. When K𝐾K is smaller than 17, the decreasing trend dominates. When K𝐾K increases beyond 17, the increasing trend dominates.

From Fig. 4, it can also be seen that the MSE under our proposed method decreases as K𝐾K grows. The reason is as follows. Define the optimal solution of bksubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k} and βksubscript𝛽𝑘\beta_{k} as bkKsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝐾b_{k}^{K} and βkKsuperscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘𝐾\beta_{k}^{K} for k=1,2,…,K𝑘12…𝐾k=1,2,...,K, respectively, when solving Problem 4 with K𝐾K mobile devices. Accordingly, the minimal cost function of Problem 4, i.e., the minimal MSE with given a𝑎a, can be expressed as EK​(a)subscript𝐸𝐾𝑎E_{K}(a). Then for any a𝑎a, we have

which means that the MSE decreases as K𝐾K grows for our proposed method.

In Fig. 4, the MSE is plotted versus the mean of channel coefficient h¯¯ℎ\bar{h}. It can be observed that the MSE decreases with h¯¯ℎ\bar{h} for all the methods. This can be explained as follows. With the increase of h¯¯ℎ\bar{h}, hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} tends to be larger, and thus, more mobile devices are included in set 𝒦1subscript𝒦1\mathcal{K}_{1}, and fewer mobile devices are included in set 𝒦2subscript𝒦2\mathcal{K}_{2}. So in our cost function ∑k=1K(a​bk​hk−βk)2+a2​σ2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscript𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘2superscript𝑎2superscript𝜎2\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2}+a^{2}\sigma^{2}, we will have more terms of (a​bk​hk−βk)2superscript𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘2\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2} equal to zero (recalling that (a​bk​hk−βk)2=0superscript𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘20\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2}=0 for k∈𝒦1𝑘subscript𝒦1k\in\mathcal{K}_{1}). For the terms of (a​bk​hk−βk)2superscript𝑎subscript𝑏𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝛽𝑘2\left(ab_{k}h_{k}-\beta_{k}\right)^{2} for k∈𝒦2𝑘subscript𝒦2k\in\mathcal{K}_{2}, although they cannot be equal to be zero, they have a higher chance to get a smaller value thanks to the increase of hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}. Thus, the MSE of our proposed method decreases. Due to a similar reason, the MSE of the COP method also decreases, recalling the fact that the COP method is actually to solve our Problem 2 by setting Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} as Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}.

In Fig. 4, the MSE is plotted versus the variance of noise σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. It can be seen that the MSE increases as σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} grows for both our proposed method and the COP method. For our proposed method, the reason can be explained as follows. VII-B Training Performance Improvement

In this sub-section, the performance of training a neural network ResNet-18 through our proposed method is analyzed and compared with benchmark methods.

Fig. 6 and Fig. 6 present the performance of training ResNet-18 based on CIFAR10 dataset by utilizing our proposed method and benchmark methods. It can be observed that our proposed method trends to outperform the benchmark methods as the communication round T𝑇T grows, in terms of not only test accuracy but also training loss. This verifies that our effort on reducing the MSE for gradient aggregation can help to improve training performance.

In Fig. 8 and Fig. 8, the performance comparison for training ResNet-18 is evaluated on another dataset CIFAR100. Results similar to Fig. 6 and 6 can be also obtained. This strengthens the meaningfulness of our efforts on reducing the MSE for gradient aggregation.

Define (bkmax)2/σ2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘2superscript𝜎2{\left(b_{k}^{\max}\right)^{2}}/{\sigma^{2}} as the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, in Fig. 10 and Fig. 10, we plot how the test accuracy varies with the SNR for our proposed method, under CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets respectively. As a comparison, the performance of the traditional FedSGD method [5], which is noise free for aggregation, is also plotted. From Fig. 10 and Fig. 10, it can be observed that as the SNR goes up, the test accuracy of our proposed method trends to increase and approaches to the performance of the FedSGD method. These results offer such an inspiration for improving the test accuracy of our proposed method: We can increase bkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘b_{k}^{\max} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} to overcome the negative effect of additive noise for aggregation to achieve a similar performance like the noise free aggregation method, such as the FedSGD.

In Fig. 12 and Fig. 12, by utilizing our proposed method, the test accuracy and training loss for training ResNet-18 under dataset CIFAR100 are plotted versus STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T}, respectively. It can be seen that as STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} grows, the performance of both test accuracy and training loss will first improve and then degrade. The reason can be explained as follows. When STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} first grows, larger set of involving data samples is beneficial for improving the training performance. As STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} further increases, the negative effect of overfitting shows up, which leads to the degradation of training performance. This result implies that it would not be optimal to use up all the available data samples, which backs up our operation on adjusting the data size for training. Moreover, this result also suggests us to choose a proper STsubscript𝑆𝑇S_{T} value in real application.

VIII Conclusion and Further Discussion

In this work, we have exploited data size selection for multiple mobile devices in a FL system powered by over-the-air computation. The amplification factor at the mobile devices and the BS and the data sizes of the mobile devices are optimized jointly to minimize the MSE. To solve the problem optimally, which is non-convex due to the coupling of multiple categories of variables and the existence of indicator function, we first simplify the cost function while preserving equivalence and perform variable transformation, and then solve the transformed problem in a two-level structure. Computation complexity of our proposed method is also analyzed, which is shown to be polynomial even in the worst case. Numerical results illustrate that our proposed method can help to further reduce MSE and improve convergence performance compared with benchmark methods. Our research results could provide helpful insights for the application of a FL system supported by over-the-air computation technique in the future. Moreover, recalling that the over-the-air computation technique can be also utilized for fusing the sensed data from multiple wireless sensors, our proposed method in this paper can be also extended to such a scenario. Specifically, when the mean value of some environmental parameter is to be estimated from a number of random observations at multiple wireless sensors, the number of random observations at each wireless sensor adopted for fusion, associated with the amplification factor at the wireless sensors and the fusion center, can be adjusted to minimize the data fusion MSE with the help of our proposed method as well.

This completes the proof.

Appendix B Proof of Lemma 2

For the mapping from the set of {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\} to the set of {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\}, which is defined in (7), it can be easily checked that for any set of {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\} satisfying (39a) and (39b), the associated {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\}, which are calculated according to (7), could always satisfy the constraints of (12) and (13). This proves the existence of the mapping from the set of {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\} restricted by (39a) and (39b) to the set of {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\} defined by (12) and (13).

Next we need to prove the existence of the mapping from the set of {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\} satisfying (12) and (13) to the set of {Sk}subscript𝑆𝑘\{S_{k}\} defined by (39a) and (39b). For a set of {βk}subscript𝛽𝑘\{\beta_{k}\} satisfying (12) and (13), say β~1subscript~𝛽1\tilde{\beta}_{1}, β~2subscript~𝛽2\tilde{\beta}_{2}, …, β~Ksubscript~𝛽𝐾\tilde{\beta}_{K}, define

Ξ~=maxk∈𝒦⁡β~kDk,~Ξsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript~𝛽𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘\tilde{\Xi}=\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{\tilde{\beta}_{k}}{D_{k}}, (40)

where the optimal k𝑘k in (40) is denoted as k∗superscript𝑘k^{*}. It can be found that the Ξ~~Ξ\tilde{\Xi} given in (40) satisfies

Ξ~=β~k∗Dk∗≤βk∗maxDk∗=1ST.~Ξsubscript~𝛽superscript𝑘subscript𝐷superscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛽superscript𝑘subscript𝐷superscript𝑘1subscript𝑆𝑇\tilde{\Xi}=\frac{\tilde{\beta}_{k^{*}}}{D_{k^{*}}}\leq\frac{\beta_{k^{*}}^{\max}}{D_{k^{*}}}=\frac{1}{S_{T}}. (41)

We then generate S~k=β~kΞ~subscript~𝑆𝑘subscript~𝛽𝑘~Ξ\tilde{S}_{k}=\frac{\tilde{\beta}_{k}}{\tilde{\Xi}} for k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}, and we have

S~k=β~k/Ξ~≤β~k​Dkβ~k≤Dk,∀k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript~𝑆𝑘subscript~𝛽𝑘~Ξsubscript~𝛽𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘subscript~𝛽𝑘subscript𝐷𝑘for-all𝑘𝒦\tilde{S}_{k}=\tilde{\beta}_{k}/\tilde{\Xi}\leq\tilde{\beta}_{k}\frac{D_{k}}{\tilde{\beta}_{k}}\leq D_{k},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, (42)

∑k=1KS~k=∑k=1Kβ~kΞ~=1Ξ~≥ST.superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript~𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript~𝛽𝑘~Ξ1~Ξsubscript𝑆𝑇\sum_{k=1}^{K}\tilde{S}_{k}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\tilde{\beta}_{k}}{\tilde{\Xi}}=\frac{1}{\tilde{\Xi}}\geq S_{T}. (43)

Appendix C Proof of Lemma 3

In case that the set 𝒦1​(a)subscript𝒦1𝑎\mathcal{K}_{1}(a) and the set 𝒦2​(a)subscript𝒦2𝑎\mathcal{K}_{2}(a) keep unchanged, it can be checked that the function P​(a,x)𝑃𝑎𝑥P(a,x) is non-decreasing with both a𝑎a and x𝑥x. Hence for Problem 6, as a𝑎a grows, the feasible region of x𝑥x will not shrink (or will enlarge), which will lead to the nonincrease of its minimal cost function, i.e., F​(a)𝐹𝑎F(a).

This completes the proof.

Appendix D Proof of Lemma 4

The proof is completed within two steps. In the first step, we show that the function P​(a,x)𝑃𝑎𝑥P(a,x) is concave function with respect to (a,x)Tsuperscript𝑎𝑥𝑇(a,x)^{T}. This is because the term min⁡(a​hk​bkmax+x,βkmax)𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑥superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\min\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}+x,\beta_{k}^{\max}\right) is a concave function with (a,x)Tsuperscript𝑎𝑥𝑇(a,x)^{T} considering that it is the minimization of two linear functions with (a,x)Tsuperscript𝑎𝑥𝑇(a,x)^{T}, i.e., (a​hk​bkmax+x)𝑎subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑏𝑘𝑥\left(ah_{k}b_{k}^{\max}+x\right) and (0⋅a+0⋅x+βkmax)⋅0𝑎⋅0𝑥superscriptsubscript𝛽𝑘\left(0\cdot a+0\cdot x+\beta_{k}^{\max}\right).

In the second step, suppose the optimal x𝑥x of Problem 6 when a=a†𝑎superscript𝑎†a=a^{{\dagger}} is x†superscript𝑥†x^{{\dagger}}, and the optimal x𝑥x of Problem 6 when a=a‡𝑎superscript𝑎‡a=a^{{\ddagger}} is x‡superscript𝑥‡x^{{\ddagger}}. Then we have P​(a†,x†)≥1𝑃superscript𝑎†superscript𝑥†1P(a^{{\dagger}},x^{{\dagger}})\geq 1 and P​(a‡,x‡)≥1𝑃superscript𝑎‡superscript𝑥‡1P(a^{{\ddagger}},x^{{\ddagger}})\geq 1. For any θ∈[0,1]𝜃01\theta\in[0,1], we have

1=θ+(1−θ)≤θ​P​(a†,x†)+(1−θ)​P​(a‡,x†)≤(a)P​(θ​a†+(1−θ)​a‡,θ​x†+(1−θ)​x‡)1𝜃1𝜃𝜃𝑃superscript𝑎†superscript𝑥†1𝜃𝑃superscript𝑎‡superscript𝑥†𝑎𝑃𝜃superscript𝑎†1𝜃superscript𝑎‡𝜃superscript𝑥†1𝜃superscript𝑥‡\begin{split}1=&~{}\theta+\left(1-\theta\right)\\ \leq&~{}\theta P(a^{{\dagger}},x^{{\dagger}})+\left(1-\theta\right)P(a^{{\ddagger}},x^{{\dagger}})\\ \overset{(a)}{\leq}&~{}P\left(\theta a^{{\dagger}}+(1-\theta)a^{{\ddagger}},\theta x^{{\dagger}}+(1-\theta)x^{{\ddagger}}\right)\end{split} (44)

where (a)𝑎(a) holds since the function P​(a,x)𝑃𝑎𝑥P(a,x) is a concave function with (a,x)Tsuperscript𝑎𝑥𝑇(a,x)^{T}. According to the statement of Problem 6, x=(θ​x†+(1−θ)​x‡)𝑥𝜃superscript𝑥†1𝜃superscript𝑥‡x=\left(\theta x^{{\dagger}}+(1-\theta)x^{{\ddagger}}\right) is a feasible solution of Problem 6 when a=(θ​a†+(1−θ)​a‡)𝑎𝜃superscript𝑎†1𝜃superscript𝑎‡a=\left(\theta a^{{\dagger}}+(1-\theta)a^{{\ddagger}}\right), which is definitely no less than F​(θ​a†+(1−θ)​a‡)𝐹𝜃superscript𝑎†1𝜃superscript𝑎‡F\left(\theta a^{{\dagger}}+(1-\theta)a^{{\ddagger}}\right). θ​F​(a†)+(1−θ)​F​(a‡)=θ​x†+(1−θ)​x‡≥F​(θ​a†+(1−θ)​a‡),𝜃𝐹superscript𝑎†1𝜃𝐹superscript𝑎‡𝜃superscript𝑥†1𝜃superscript𝑥‡𝐹𝜃superscript𝑎†1𝜃superscript𝑎‡\begin{split}&~{}\theta F(a^{{\dagger}})+(1-\theta)F(a^{{\ddagger}})\\ =&~{}\theta x^{{\dagger}}+(1-\theta)x^{{\ddagger}}\\ \geq&~{}F\left(\theta a^{{\dagger}}+(1-\theta)a^{{\ddagger}}\right),\end{split} (45)

which proves the convexity of function F​(a)𝐹𝑎F(a) with a𝑎a.
